title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence and corruption in those regions. Additionally, drug trafficking in Central America, Mexico, and other countries contributes to instability. Drug trafficking of cocaine and heroin in Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and other Caribbean countries fuels organized crime, threatening law enforcement, political institutions, and citizen security. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico and along the US-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico also traffic women and girls into the United States. According to the Department of State's June 2009 Trafficking in Persons report, organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the United States for commercial sexual exploitation. Extremist groups in the Western Hemisphere, such as FARC and Hezbollah, use drug trafficking to finance terrorist activities. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008 totaled about $11.3 billion. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, focusing on international drug policies in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve existing counternarcotics policies. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, drug interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. The impact of various initiatives in curbing drug production and trafficking will be evaluated. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess technology deployment against drug cartels, curb chemical precursor trafficking, evaluate US drug certification process, analyze population's drug demand, and review drug prevention and treatment programs. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess the United States drug prevention and treatment programs, including anti-drug coalitions and drug courts, evaluate the extent of illicit drug consumption driven by addiction, and make recommendations to improve policies on reducing drug supply and demand. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will evaluate US drug control policies, assess support for reducing illicit drug supply and demand, and coordinate with various entities in the Western Hemisphere. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will consult with various leaders and the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission to increase effectiveness. A report must be submitted to relevant committees within 12 months of the first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report to relevant committees containing recommendations, findings, and conclusions within 12 months of the first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report with recommendations, findings, and conclusions, including input from leaders and organizations consulted, which will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission consists of ten members appointed promptly after the Act's enactment. Members will have travel expenses covered while away for Commission duties. A quorum is set at six members, with a Chairperson selected within 60 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold meetings, conduct hearings, and access necessary resources from various government agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission, including the Department of Defense and other government agencies, can request access to resources in writing. The General Services Administration provides office space and administrative support as needed. The Commission can use the United States mails and enter into contracts with Federal and State agencies. The Commission is authorized to enter into contracts with Federal and State agencies, private firms, institutions, and individuals for activities necessary to its duties. Contracts cannot extend beyond the Commission's termination date. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff at a specified pay rate. The Commission may also appoint additional personnel without following certain regulations regarding appointments and pay rates. The Executive Director of the Commission can appoint staff at a specified pay rate, without following certain regulations. The Commission may also procure temporary services and detail government employees to assist in its duties. SEC. 9. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 authorized to carry out the Act without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 10. Sunset: The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission terminates 60 days after submitting its report to Congress.
